content: Are people against having something called is_upset or up_set? I think this standard terminology is pretty innocuous and we already have many objects whose name conflicts with a real world one.
I think the underscore solves this issue.

Okay, so what name do you want me to use for

  • The unbundled predicate (currently is_upset)
  • The bundled type (currently up_set)
Sounds good. Does anyone else have opinions? @Bhavik Mehta ?
Patrick's suggestion is fine by me. You also call these sets "upper sets" in the docstring and PR title, so is_upper_set and upper_set would make sense too.

That said, another consideration is the fact that "up_set" or "upset" or whichever name we go with isn't an adjective, so perhaps it shouldn't have the prefix "is_", as discussed in https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/116395-maths/topic/.60is_foo.60.20v.20.60foo.60 and https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113488-general/topic/Noun.2Fadjective.2Fverb.20naming.20conventions.20for.20defs.20in.20mathlib
So perhaps that suggests "is_upclosed" or "is_up_closed" would be better.
I want something short and catchy, is_upper_set is a bit too long to my taste (although it has the advantage that upper and lower have the same number of characters)

is_up_closed/up_set and is_down_closed/down_set?

(When I see is_upset s I almost want to ask s what's the matter...)
I would argue that brings comedy value!
example : is_upset s ↔ is_down s := by tauto
